newsitem.title: COTE D'IVOIRE: Ivorian cocoa arrivals slow ahead of new season.
newsitem.headline: Ivorian cocoa arrivals slow ahead of new season.

text.p: Cocoa arrivals in Ivory Coast appear slow ahead of the 1996/97 marketing season, expected to open on Wednesday or Thursday, and the announcement of official farm-gate prices, exporters said.
They said arrivals had been slowed down by people holding back for a decision on price.
"Average weekly arrivals are on average 5,000-6,000 tonnes, 7,000 maximum, for both Abidjan and San Pedro (combined)," one Abidjan-based trader said on Tuesday.
"I would say arrivals since the beginning of October are at least 20,000 tonnes, but it is very difficult to say," said a second Abidjan exporter.
Estimated arrivals by this time in the 1995/96 season ranged from 22,000 to 47,000 tonnes, about the same as during the 1994/95 season.

October 1995 presidential elections and political and ethnic violence in part of the western cocoa growing zone slowed arrivals at the start of the 1995/96 season, which produced a record of around 1.2 million tonnes.

Exporters in Abidjan and San Pedro said quality of arrivals was very good and pod count estimates ranged from 95 to 100 beans per 100 grammes. "Quality is excellent, and average pod count is between 95-98. There are no problems with humidity," said one San Pedro exporter.
On farm-gate prices, exporters said the government was rumoured to be pressing for an increase from 320 CFA francs per kilo to 340, but had run into World Bank resistance.
"The World Bank want to push it down to 325 CFA francs," an Abidjan-based exporter said.
"I have heard rumours that the World Bank and the government can't agree on a price," one exporter said, adding that this might explain the delayed start to the season.
The opening of the season has been delayed by about three weeks. The government has given no explanation.
Commodities Minister Guy-Alain Gauze told reporters on Monday at a two-day ministerial review in Gabon of the 1993 International Cocoa Agreement that the season would open in two to three days.
"Everybody is saying that the season will open in two days time," said one Abidjan exporter.
Officials said the government would be meeting under Prime Minister Daniel Kablan Duncan on Tuesday.
Formal announcements are usually made the following day after a full cabinet meeting under President Henri Konan Bedie.
The latest rumour was that an announcement would coincide with the start of a major ruling Democratic Party congress next Monday, one industry source said.
Exporters added that the government was keen to unveil a price before the start of the congress.

Some linked the delay to the start of the marketing campaign to the appointment last month of a new head of Ivory Coast's Caistab marketing board, Yves-Marie Koissy, who previously worked at the International Monetary Fund. "I think the new director coming in has slowed things down," one said.

Gauze said on Monday that 1996/97 production would be between 900,000 and 950,000 tonnes. "This is a very important element as it coincides with World Bank and International Monetary Fund plans," he said.
